  ---

speculation. Defining a term avoids ambiguity and rhetoric usage o=
f words
("doublespeak", as in "1984"). For this brief discussion, I hold "S=
amurai"
as a social class, and, hence, any statement containing to members =
of a
Samurai class before its ascension unto a social class cannot be consi=
dered
valid. If you define "Samurai" as "retainer", then there were members=
 of a
Samurai class before it was turned into a social class. What should b=
e
avoided, if possible, is the usage of the word "Samurai" with both meanin=
gs,
under a single context.

nsider the "Language Systems" Philosophical School of Thought, if

 Think of any given "due process of law" - if the highest court in
a countr=
y utters "the sky is yellow", no matter any what other language (as

entific) holds, the sky is yellow, because the State will have the
power to=
 enforce the ruling. Will it make the sky turn yellow before other
language=
 systems (as the ones pertaining to human perception)? Definitely

ver, the given State may enforce the ruling, for, before the Legal
Language=
 System, "the sky is yellow".
  That=B4s why the person uttering the langua=
ge is so important: dynamic
validity arises from the utterance process and =
uttering person. Static
validity - the contents of the ruling - is assessed=

ent - however valid,
